title: Deep Graphical Feature Learning for the Feature Matching Problem
abstract: The feature matching problem is a fundamental problem in various areas of computer vision including image registration, tracking and motion analysis. Rich local representation is a key part of efficient feature matching methods. However, when the local features are limited to the coordinate of key points, it becomes challenging to extract rich local representations. Traditional approaches use pairwise or higher order handcrafted geometric features to get robust matching; this requires solving NP-hard assignment problems. In this paper, we address this problem by proposing a graph neural network model to transform coordinates of feature points into local features. With our local features, the traditional NP-hard assignment problems are replaced with a simple assignment problem which can be solved efficiently. Promising results on both synthetic and real datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.
problem_description_natural: The paper addresses the geometric feature matching problem where only point coordinates are available as input features. Traditional methods rely on higher-order geometric features (e.g., edge lengths, angles) which lead to Quadratic or Higher Order Assignment Problems that are NP-hard. The authors propose learning rich local features from point coordinates using a graph neural network (specifically, a Compositional Message Passing Neural Network), thereby reducing the matching problem to a Linear Assignment Problem solvable efficiently via the Hungarian/Munkres algorithm.

lp_model.objective: $\max \sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n S_1(f_j, g_i) x_{ij} + \sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n \sum_{a=1}^n \sum_{b=1}^n S_2([f_a, f_b], [g_i, g_j]) x_{ia} x_{jb} + \cdots$
variables: $x_{ij}$: binary decision variable, $x_{ij}=1$ if point $f_i$ in set $\mathcal{F}$ is matched to point $g_j$ in set $\mathcal{G}$

raw_latex_model: $$\max_{\pi \in \Pi(n)} S(\pi) = \max_{\pi \in \Pi(n)} \left( \sum_{i=1}^n S_1(f_{\pi(i)}, g_i) + \sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n S_2([f_{\pi(i)}, f_{\pi(j)}], [g_i, g_j]) + \cdots \right)$$ where $\Pi(n)$ is the set of all permutations of $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, $\mathcal{F} = \{f_i\}_{i=1}^n$ and $\mathcal{G} = \{g_i\}_{i=1}^n$ are sets of feature points, and $S_1, S_2, \ldots$ are similarity functions. For geometric feature matching, $S_1$ is often zero or negligible, making it a Quadratic or Higher Order Assignment Problem.
algorithm_description: Proposed a graph neural network called Compositional Message Passing Neural Network (CMPNN) to learn rich local features from point coordinates and graph structure. After feature learning, the problem is reduced to a Linear Assignment Problem, which is solved efficiently using the Hungarian/Munkres algorithm.
